        "healthErrors": [
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78155",
            "errorMessage": "Replication health of 12-DC-1 is critical as the Azure Site Recovery mobility service software has been uninstalled from the machine.",
            "possibleCauses": "Mobility service software on the source machine has been uninstalled.",
            "recommendedAction": "\n            The source machine isn’t being replicated as the mobility service software has been uninstalled, but can be failed over to the latest available recovery point. In order to continue protecting this machine :\n            1) Disable replication for the machine. After removing the replicating machine from Azure Site Recovery perform step 2.\n            2) Enable replication for the machine to push install the mobility service software on the machine, or, install the mobility service software on the machine manually, register it to the Configuration server, and enable replication.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-09-04T11:02:00.0724708Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }

      "properties": {
        "eventCode": "SRSVMHealthChanged",
        "description": "Virtual machine health is in Critical state.",
        "eventType": "VmHealth",
        "affectedObjectFriendlyName": "ScaleWinSrc11",
        "severity": "Critical",
        "timeOfOccurrence": "2017-09-01T13:21:29.6486316Z",
        "fabricId": "/Subscriptions/7c943c1b-5122-4097-90c8-861411bdd574/resourceGroups/canaryexproute/providers/Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/IbizaV2ATest/replicationFabrics/ed8a3ab891c07617692d42795cc5042a71dbd734ff280e509cecd5a23b161a38",
        "providerSpecificDetails": {
          "instanceType": "InMageAzureV2",
          "eventType": null,
          "category": null,
          "component": null,
          "correctiveAction": null,
          "details": null,
          "summary": null,
          "siteName": "ScaleWinSrc03"
        },
        "eventSpecificDetails": null,
        "healthErrors": [
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78026",
            "errorMessage": "RPO has exceeded the configured threshold for source disks 'Disk0, Disk1'.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            The RPO for a replicating machine may be impacted if:\n            1. The machine is shutdown, the Mobility service components on the machine is not running, or the machine doesn’t have network connectivity to the process server.\n            2. The replicating machine is unable to upload changes fast enough to the process server, or the replicating machine has been flow controlled/throttled by the process server, thereby causing the machine to go into a non-data replication mode.\n            3. Recovery tag generation failures on the replicating machine.\n            4. The process server is unable to upload changes fast enough to the target/log Azure storage account (or the master target server if replicating to an on-premises site). This in turn can happen due to network connectivity issues /glitches or insufficient network throughput/bandwidth between the process server and the Azure log/target storage account.\n            5. Storage IOPs/throughput limits are being hit on the log/target storage account resulting in reduced end to end upload throughput from the process server to the log/target storage account in Azure.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          1. If there are other errors for the replicating machine, resolve them first.\n          2. See the list of recent events for the replicating machine that may be impacting the RPO of the machine by going to the events section of the recovery services vault. If there are any such events, resolve them.\n          3. Ensure that you have sufficient network bandwidth between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to on-premises site) to upload replication data, and that you are replicating to the appropriate tier of storage based on the data change rate characteristics of the replicating machine. Use the ASR deployment planner (https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-deployment-planner) to estimate the necessary network bandwidth requirements and the appropriate tier of storage to replicate to.\n\n          Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-rpo-exceeded , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-09-01T13:21:29.6486316Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          },
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78022",
            "errorMessage": "No mobility service heartbeat from the source 'ScaleWinSrc11' or the master target server 'ScaleWinSrc03' in the last 15 minutes.",
            "possibleCauses": "The mobility service is not running on the host. There is no network connectivity from the host to the configuration server.",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          Ensure that the mobility service(InMage Scout VX Agent - Sentinel/Outpost, InMage Scout Application Service) is running on the host, host is connected to a network and the configuration server is reachable from the host.\n          Read more at https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-no-heartbeat.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-09-01T13:21:29.6486316Z",

      "id": "/Subscriptions/7c943c1b-5122-4097-90c8-861411bdd574/resourceGroups/canaryexproute/providers/Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/IbizaV2ATest/replicationEvents/VmMonitoringEvent;9091884579968602146_1f520a22-c311-400a-aeeb-0057bd9091c7",
      "properties": {
        "eventCode": "SRSVMHealthChanged",
        "description": "Virtual machine health is in Critical state.",
        "eventType": "VmHealth",
        "affectedObjectFriendlyName": "ScaleWinSrc17",
        "severity": "Critical",
        "timeOfOccurrence": "2017-09-01T13:21:28.6173661Z",
        "fabricId": "/Subscriptions/7c943c1b-5122-4097-90c8-861411bdd574/resourceGroups/canaryexproute/providers/Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/IbizaV2ATest/replicationFabrics/ed8a3ab891c07617692d42795cc5042a71dbd734ff280e509cecd5a23b161a38",
        "providerSpecificDetails": {
          "instanceType": "InMageAzureV2",
          "eventType": null,
          "category": null,
          "component": null,
          "correctiveAction": null,
          "details": null,
          "summary": null,
          "siteName": "ScaleWinSrc03"
        },
        "eventSpecificDetails": null,
        "healthErrors": [
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78026",
            "errorMessage": "RPO has exceeded the configured threshold for source disks 'Disk0, Disk1'.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            The RPO for a replicating machine may be impacted if:\n            1. The machine is shutdown, the Mobility service components on the machine is not running, or the machine doesn’t have network connectivity to the process server.\n            2. The replicating machine is unable to upload changes fast enough to the process server, or the replicating machine has been flow controlled/throttled by the process server, thereby causing the machine to go into a non-data replication mode.\n            3. Recovery tag generation failures on the replicating machine.\n            4. The process server is unable to upload changes fast enough to the target/log Azure storage account (or the master target server if replicating to an on-premises site). This in turn can happen due to network connectivity issues /glitches or insufficient network throughput/bandwidth between the process server and the Azure log/target storage account.\n            5. Storage IOPs/throughput limits are being hit on the log/target storage account resulting in reduced end to end upload throughput from the process server to the log/target storage account in Azure.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          1. If there are other errors for the replicating machine, resolve them first.\n          2. See the list of recent events for the replicating machine that may be impacting the RPO of the machine by going to the events section of the recovery services vault. If there are any such events, resolve them.\n          3. Ensure that you have sufficient network bandwidth between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to on-premises site) to upload replication data, and that you are replicating to the appropriate tier of storage based on the data change rate characteristics of the replicating machine. Use the ASR deployment planner (https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-deployment-planner) to estimate the necessary network bandwidth requirements and the appropriate tier of storage to replicate to.\n\n          Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-rpo-exceeded , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-09-01T13:21:28.6173661Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          },
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78022",
            "errorMessage": "No mobility service heartbeat from the source 'ScaleWinSrc17' or the master target server 'ScaleWinSrc03' in the last 15 minutes.",
            "possibleCauses": "The mobility service is not running on the host. There is no network connectivity from the host to the configuration server.",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          Ensure that the mobility service(InMage Scout VX Agent - Sentinel/Outpost, InMage Scout Application Service) is running on the host, host is connected to a network and the configuration server is reachable from the host.\n          Read more at https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-no-heartbeat.\n        ",

        "eventType": "VmHealth",

        "fabricId": "/Subscriptions/7c943c1b-5122-4097-90c8-861411bdd574/resourceGroups/canaryexproute/providers/Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/IbizaV2ATest/replicationFabrics/ed8a3ab891c07617692d42795cc5042a71dbd734ff280e509cecd5a23b161a38",
        "providerSpecificDetails": {

          "eventType": null,
          "category": null,
          "component": null,
          "correctiveAction": null,
          "details": null,
          "summary": null,
          "siteName": "ScaleWinSrc03"
        },
        "eventSpecificDetails": null,
        "healthErrors": [
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78026",
            "errorMessage": "RPO has exceeded the configured threshold for source disks 'Disk0, Disk1'.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            The RPO for a replicating machine may be impacted if:\n            1. The machine is shutdown, the Mobility service components on the machine is not running, or the machine doesn’t have network connectivity to the process server.\n            2. The replicating machine is unable to upload changes fast enough to the process server, or the replicating machine has been flow controlled/throttled by the process server, thereby causing the machine to go into a non-data replication mode.\n            3. Recovery tag generation failures on the replicating machine.\n            4. The process server is unable to upload changes fast enough to the target/log Azure storage account (or the master target server if replicating to an on-premises site). This in turn can happen due to network connectivity issues /glitches or insufficient network throughput/bandwidth between the process server and the Azure log/target storage account.\n            5. Storage IOPs/throughput limits are being hit on the log/target storage account resulting in reduced end to end upload throughput from the process server to the log/target storage account in Azure.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          1. If there are other errors for the replicating machine, resolve them first.\n          2. See the list of recent events for the replicating machine that may be impacting the RPO of the machine by going to the events section of the recovery services vault. If there are any such events, resolve them.\n          3. Ensure that you have sufficient network bandwidth between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to on-premises site) to upload replication data, and that you are replicating to the appropriate tier of storage based on the data change rate characteristics of the replicating machine. Use the ASR deployment planner (https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-deployment-planner) to estimate the necessary network bandwidth requirements and the appropriate tier of storage to replicate to.\n\n          Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-rpo-exceeded , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-09-01T11:59:04.4739782Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          },
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78172",
            "errorMessage": "No heartbeat received from the mobility service on the source machine 'ScaleWinSrc07' in the last 15 minutes.",
            "possibleCauses": "The mobility service is not running on the source machine or there is no network connectivity from the source machine to the configuration server.",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          Ensure that\n          1) The \"InMage Scout VX Agent - Sentinel/Outpost\" service is running on the source machine\n          2) The source machine has network connectivity to the configuration server on the configuration server tcp port 443.\n          Read more at https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-no-heartbeat.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-09-01T11:59:04.4739782Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }

        "providerSpecificDetails": {

          "category": null,
          "component": null,
          "correctiveAction": null,
          "details": null,

          "siteName": "Grace-V2A-1"
        },
        "eventSpecificDetails": null,
        "healthErrors": [
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78026",
            "errorMessage": "RPO has exceeded the configured threshold for source disks '/dev/sda, /dev/sdb'.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            The RPO for a replicating machine may be impacted if:\n            1. The machine is shutdown, the Mobility service components on the machine is not running, or the machine doesn’t have network connectivity to the process server.\n            2. The replicating machine is unable to upload changes fast enough to the process server, or the replicating machine has been flow controlled/throttled by the process server, thereby causing the machine to go into a non-data replication mode.\n            3. Recovery tag generation failures on the replicating machine.\n            4. The process server is unable to upload changes fast enough to the target/log Azure storage account (or the master target server if replicating to an on-premises site). This in turn can happen due to network connectivity issues /glitches or insufficient network throughput/bandwidth between the process server and the Azure log/target storage account.\n            5. Storage IOPs/throughput limits are being hit on the log/target storage account resulting in reduced end to end upload throughput from the process server to the log/target storage account in Azure.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          1. If there are other errors for the replicating machine, resolve them first.\n          2. See the list of recent events for the replicating machine that may be impacting the RPO of the machine by going to the events section of the recovery services vault. If there are any such events, resolve them.\n          3. Ensure that you have sufficient network bandwidth between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to on-premises site) to upload replication data, and that you are replicating to the appropriate tier of storage based on the data change rate characteristics of the replicating machine. Use the ASR deployment planner (https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-deployment-planner) to estimate the necessary network bandwidth requirements and the appropriate tier of storage to replicate to.\n\n          Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-rpo-exceeded , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-09-01T11:05:56.8441561Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          },
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78028",
            "errorMessage": "Data upload blocked for the '/dev/sda, /dev/sdb' disk's replication on the source machine.",
            "possibleCauses": "The process server has not received any data from the source machine in the last 30 minutes.",
            "recommendedAction": "Ensure that the network connectivity exists between the source machine and the process server. Check to see if the mobility service (InMage Scout VX Agent - Sentinel/Outpost, InMage Scout Application Service) is running on the source server.",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-09-01T11:05:56.8441561Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          },
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78174",
            "errorMessage": "No heartbeat received from the mobility service on the source machine 'GRACE-Lin-3' in the last 15 minutes.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            1. The mobility service is not running on the source machine\n            2. There is no network connectivity from the source machine to the configuration server.\n            3. The source machine is not up\n            4. The source machine is running a version of the mobility service older than 9.4 and is unable to authenticate with the configuration server\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          Ensure that\n          1) The source machine is up and that the mobility service(\"InMage Scout VX Agent - Sentinel/Outpost\", and  \"InMage Scout Application Service\") is running on the host\n          2) The source machines has network connectivity to the configuration server on the configuration server tcp port 443.\n          3) If the mobility service version on the machine is 9.3 or lower, upgrade to the latest version of the mobility service\n          Read more at https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-no-heartbeat.\n        ",

            "errorCode": "90078",
            "errorMessage": "Replication for ScaleWinSrc02 (10.150.209.239) (Disk0) hasn't progressed in the last 60 minutes.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n        Replication may not be progressing due to\n        1. Network connectivity issues between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to an on-premises site)\n        2. The Azure subscription of the target storage account has been disabled.\n        3. Process server is unable to upload changes to the log/target Azure storage account, due to authentication errors.\n    ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n        1. Ensure that there is network connectivity between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master-target server if replicating to an on-premises site.)\n        2. Ensure that the \"Microsoft Azure Recovery Services Agent\", and \"InMage Scout Vx Agent - Sentinel/Outpost\" services are running on the process server machine. Try restarting these services on the process server.\n        3. Go to the Windows event viewer on the process server machine, and check for events under Applications and Services logs\\MicrosoftAzureRecoveryServices\\Replication and resolve any errors.\n        4. Log in to the replicating machine and look for the line \"Peer certificate cannot be authenticated with given CA certificates\" in the svagents.log file at  [Mobility service install location]\\ASR\\Agent\\svagents.log. If you find the line, ensure that you are running mobility service version 9.4 or higher and if not update your version.\n\n        Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-replication-not-progressing , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        If the issue persists, contact support.\n\n    ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-08-31T07:13:54.8817253Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }
    },

        "providerSpecificDetails": {

          "siteName": "V2A-W2K12-400"
        },
        "eventSpecificDetails": null,
        "healthErrors": [
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78026",
            "errorMessage": "RPO has exceeded the configured threshold for source disks 'Disk0'.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            The RPO for a replicating machine may be impacted if:\n            1. The machine is shutdown, the Mobility service components on the machine is not running, or the machine doesn’t have network connectivity to the process server.\n            2. The replicating machine is unable to upload changes fast enough to the process server, or the replicating machine has been flow controlled/throttled by the process server, thereby causing the machine to go into a non-data replication mode.\n            3. Recovery tag generation failures on the replicating machine.\n            4. The process server is unable to upload changes fast enough to the target/log Azure storage account (or the master target server if replicating to an on-premises site). This in turn can happen due to network connectivity issues /glitches or insufficient network throughput/bandwidth between the process server and the Azure log/target storage account.\n            5. Storage IOPs/throughput limits are being hit on the log/target storage account resulting in reduced end to end upload throughput from the process server to the log/target storage account in Azure.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          1. If there are other errors for the replicating machine, resolve them first.\n          2. See the list of recent events for the replicating machine that may be impacting the RPO of the machine by going to the events section of the recovery services vault. If there are any such events, resolve them.\n          3. Ensure that you have sufficient network bandwidth between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to on-premises site) to upload replication data, and that you are replicating to the appropriate tier of storage based on the data change rate characteristics of the replicating machine. Use the ASR deployment planner (https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-deployment-planner) to estimate the necessary network bandwidth requirements and the appropriate tier of storage to replicate to.\n\n          Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-rpo-exceeded , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-08-31T01:50:34.090907Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,

    {
      "name": "VmMonitoringEvent;9091885858514023250_bb2f3a1c-52a5-4038-aca8-f2e488df7d02",
      "type": "Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/replicationEvents",
      "id": "/Subscriptions/7c943c1b-5122-4097-90c8-861411bdd574/resourceGroups/canaryexproute/providers/Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/IbizaV2ATest/replicationEvents/VmMonitoringEvent;9091885858514023250_bb2f3a1c-52a5-4038-aca8-f2e488df7d02",
      "properties": {
        "eventCode": "InMageCommon_ECH0007",
        "description": "RPO threshold exceeded.",
        "eventType": "VmHealth",
        "affectedObjectFriendlyName": "win-4003",
        "severity": "Critical",
        "timeOfOccurrence": "2017-08-31T01:50:34.0752557Z",
        "fabricId": "/Subscriptions/7c943c1b-5122-4097-90c8-861411bdd574/resourceGroups/canaryexproute/providers/Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/IbizaV2ATest/replicationFabrics/3b1adab302bbd6fc3d81a0bc60ddc477055ac3df2a020707618d4d512451e03a",
        "providerSpecificDetails": {
          "instanceType": "InMageAzureV2",
          "eventType": null,
          "category": null,
          "component": null,
          "correctiveAction": null,
          "details": null,
          "summary": null,
          "siteName": "V2A-W2K12-400"
        },
        "eventSpecificDetails": null,
        "healthErrors": [
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78026",
            "errorMessage": "RPO has exceeded the configured threshold for source disks 'Disk0'.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            The RPO for a replicating machine may be impacted if:\n            1. The machine is shutdown, the Mobility service components on the machine is not running, or the machine doesn’t have network connectivity to the process server.\n            2. The replicating machine is unable to upload changes fast enough to the process server, or the replicating machine has been flow controlled/throttled by the process server, thereby causing the machine to go into a non-data replication mode.\n            3. Recovery tag generation failures on the replicating machine.\n            4. The process server is unable to upload changes fast enough to the target/log Azure storage account (or the master target server if replicating to an on-premises site). This in turn can happen due to network connectivity issues /glitches or insufficient network throughput/bandwidth between the process server and the Azure log/target storage account.\n            5. Storage IOPs/throughput limits are being hit on the log/target storage account resulting in reduced end to end upload throughput from the process server to the log/target storage account in Azure.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          1. If there are other errors for the replicating machine, resolve them first.\n          2. See the list of recent events for the replicating machine that may be impacting the RPO of the machine by going to the events section of the recovery services vault. If there are any such events, resolve them.\n          3. Ensure that you have sufficient network bandwidth between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to on-premises site) to upload replication data, and that you are replicating to the appropriate tier of storage based on the data change rate characteristics of the replicating machine. Use the ASR deployment planner (https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-deployment-planner) to estimate the necessary network bandwidth requirements and the appropriate tier of storage to replicate to.\n\n          Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-rpo-exceeded , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-08-31T01:50:34.0752557Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }
    },

      "name": "VmMonitoringEvent;9091886228620045732_5401fbd0-a137-4b19-bc06-fde9caf6720f",
      "type": "Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/replicationEvents",
      "id": "/Subscriptions/7c943c1b-5122-4097-90c8-861411bdd574/resourceGroups/canaryexproute/providers/Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/IbizaV2ATest/replicationEvents/VmMonitoringEvent;9091886228620045732_5401fbd0-a137-4b19-bc06-fde9caf6720f",
      "properties": {
        "eventCode": "SRSVMHealthChanged",
        "description": "Virtual machine health is in Critical state.",
        "eventType": "VmHealth",
        "affectedObjectFriendlyName": "NS-WIN-SRC3",
        "severity": "Critical",
        "timeOfOccurrence": "2017-08-30T15:33:43.4730075Z",
        "fabricId": "/Subscriptions/7c943c1b-5122-4097-90c8-861411bdd574/resourceGroups/canaryexproute/providers/Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/IbizaV2ATest/replicationFabrics/3b1adab302bbd6fc3d81a0bc60ddc477055ac3df2a020707618d4d512451e03a",
        "providerSpecificDetails": {
          "instanceType": "InMageAzureV2",
          "eventType": null,
          "category": null,
          "component": null,
          "correctiveAction": null,
          "details": null,
          "summary": null,
          "siteName": "V2A-W2K12-400"
        },
        "eventSpecificDetails": null,
        "healthErrors": [
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78026",
            "errorMessage": "RPO has exceeded the configured threshold for source disks 'Disk0'.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            The RPO for a replicating machine may be impacted if:\n            1. The machine is shutdown, the Mobility service components on the machine is not running, or the machine doesn’t have network connectivity to the process server.\n            2. The replicating machine is unable to upload changes fast enough to the process server, or the replicating machine has been flow controlled/throttled by the process server, thereby causing the machine to go into a non-data replication mode.\n            3. Recovery tag generation failures on the replicating machine.\n            4. The process server is unable to upload changes fast enough to the target/log Azure storage account (or the master target server if replicating to an on-premises site). This in turn can happen due to network connectivity issues /glitches or insufficient network throughput/bandwidth between the process server and the Azure log/target storage account.\n            5. Storage IOPs/throughput limits are being hit on the log/target storage account resulting in reduced end to end upload throughput from the process server to the log/target storage account in Azure.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          1. If there are other errors for the replicating machine, resolve them first.\n          2. See the list of recent events for the replicating machine that may be impacting the RPO of the machine by going to the events section of the recovery services vault. If there are any such events, resolve them.\n          3. Ensure that you have sufficient network bandwidth between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to on-premises site) to upload replication data, and that you are replicating to the appropriate tier of storage based on the data change rate characteristics of the replicating machine. Use the ASR deployment planner (https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-deployment-planner) to estimate the necessary network bandwidth requirements and the appropriate tier of storage to replicate to.\n\n          Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-rpo-exceeded , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-08-30T15:33:43.4730075Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }
    },

            "recommendedAction": "\n            The source machine isn’t being replicated as the mobility service software has been uninstalled, but can be failed over to the latest available recovery point.       "properties": {
        "eventCode": "SRSVMHealthChanged",
        "description": "Virtual machine health is in Critical state.",
        "eventType": "VmHealth",
        "affectedObjectFriendlyName": "win-4001",
        "severity": "Critical",
        "timeOfOccurrence": "2017-08-30T12:13:55.2352983Z",
        "fabricId": "/Subscriptions/7c943c1b-5122-4097-90c8-861411bdd574/resourceGroups/canaryexproute/providers/Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/IbizaV2ATest/replicationFabrics/3b1adab302bbd6fc3d81a0bc60ddc477055ac3df2a020707618d4d512451e03a",
        "providerSpecificDetails": {
          "instanceType": "InMageAzureV2",
          "eventType": null,
          "category": null,
          "component": null,
          "correctiveAction": null,
          "details": null,
          "summary": null,
          "siteName": "V2A-W2K12-400"
        },
        "eventSpecificDetails": null,
        "healthErrors": [
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78026",
            "errorMessage": "RPO has exceeded the configured threshold for source disks 'Disk0'.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            The RPO for a replicating machine may be impacted if:\n            1. The machine is shutdown, the Mobility service components on the machine is not running, or the machine doesn’t have network connectivity to the process server.\n            2. The replicating machine is unable to upload changes fast enough to the process server, or the replicating machine has been flow controlled/throttled by the process server, thereby causing the machine to go into a non-data replication mode.\n            3. Recovery tag generation failures on the replicating machine.\n            4. The process server is unable to upload changes fast enough to the target/log Azure storage account (or the master target server if replicating to an on-premises site). This in turn can happen due to network connectivity issues /glitches or insufficient network throughput/bandwidth between the process server and the Azure log/target storage account.\n            5. Storage IOPs/throughput limits are being hit on the log/target storage account resulting in reduced end to end upload throughput from the process server to the log/target storage account in Azure.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          1. If there are other errors for the replicating machine, resolve them first.\n          2. See the list of recent events for the replicating machine that may be impacting the RPO of the machine by going to the events section of the recovery services vault. If there are any such events, resolve them.\n          3. Ensure that you have sufficient network bandwidth between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to on-premises site) to upload replication data, and that you are replicating to the appropriate tier of storage based on the data change rate characteristics of the replicating machine. Use the ASR deployment planner (https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-deployment-planner) to estimate the necessary network bandwidth requirements and the appropriate tier of storage to replicate to.\n\n          Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-rpo-exceeded , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-08-30T12:13:55.2352983Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }
    },

          {

            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "90078",
            "errorMessage": "Replication for GRACE-V2A-WIN-1 (10.150.2.255) (Disk0, Disk1) hasn't progressed in the last 60 minutes.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n        Replication may not be progressing due to\n        1. Network connectivity issues between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to an on-premises site)\n        2. The Azure subscription of the target storage account has been disabled.\n        3. Process server is unable to upload changes to the log/target Azure storage account, due to authentication errors.\n    ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n        1. Ensure that there is network connectivity between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master-target server if replicating to an on-premises site.)\n        2. Ensure that the \"Microsoft Azure Recovery Services Agent\", and \"InMage Scout Vx Agent - Sentinel/Outpost\" services are running on the process server machine. Try restarting these services on the process server.\n        3. Go to the Windows event viewer on the process server machine, and check for events under Applications and Services logs\\MicrosoftAzureRecoveryServices\\Replication and resolve any errors.\n        4. Log in to the replicating machine and look for the line \"Peer certificate cannot be authenticated with given CA certificates\" in the svagents.log file at  [Mobility service install location]\\ASR\\Agent\\svagents.log. If you find the line, ensure that you are running mobility service version 9.4 or higher and if not update your version.\n\n        Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-replication-not-progressing , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        If the issue persists, contact support.\n\n    ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-08-30T12:00:25.7180629Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }

      "id": "/Subscriptions/7c943c1b-5122-4097-90c8-861411bdd574/resourceGroups/canaryexproute/providers/Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/IbizaV2ATest/replicationEvents/VmMonitoringEvent;9091886368389788925_8db2f09b-e47c-4a23-a817-d81ff58fd0b3",
      "properties": {
        "eventCode": "InMageCommon_ECH0007",
        "description": "RPO threshold exceeded.",
        "eventType": "VmHealth",
        "affectedObjectFriendlyName": "win-4001",
        "severity": "Critical",
        "timeOfOccurrence": "2017-08-30T11:40:46.4986882Z",
        "fabricId": "/Subscriptions/7c943c1b-5122-4097-90c8-861411bdd574/resourceGroups/canaryexproute/providers/Microsoft.RecoveryServices/vaults/IbizaV2ATest/replicationFabrics/3b1adab302bbd6fc3d81a0bc60ddc477055ac3df2a020707618d4d512451e03a",
        "providerSpecificDetails": {
          "instanceType": "InMageAzureV2",
          "eventType": null,
          "category": null,
          "component": null,
          "correctiveAction": null,
          "details": null,
          "summary": null,
          "siteName": "V2A-W2K12-400"
        },
        "eventSpecificDetails": null,
        "healthErrors": [
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78026",
            "errorMessage": "RPO has exceeded the configured threshold for source disks 'Disk0'.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            The RPO for a replicating machine may be impacted if:\n            1. The machine is shutdown, the Mobility service components on the machine is not running, or the machine doesn’t have network connectivity to the process server.\n            2. The replicating machine is unable to upload changes fast enough to the process server, or the replicating machine has been flow controlled/throttled by the process server, thereby causing the machine to go into a non-data replication mode.\n            3. Recovery tag generation failures on the replicating machine.\n            4. The process server is unable to upload changes fast enough to the target/log Azure storage account (or the master target server if replicating to an on-premises site). This in turn can happen due to network connectivity issues /glitches or insufficient network throughput/bandwidth between the process server and the Azure log/target storage account.\n            5. Storage IOPs/throughput limits are being hit on the log/target storage account resulting in reduced end to end upload throughput from the process server to the log/target storage account in Azure.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          1. If there are other errors for the replicating machine, resolve them first.\n          2. See the list of recent events for the replicating machine that may be impacting the RPO of the machine by going to the events section of the recovery services vault. If there are any such events, resolve them.\n          3. Ensure that you have sufficient network bandwidth between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to on-premises site) to upload replication data, and that you are replicating to the appropriate tier of storage based on the data change rate characteristics of the replicating machine. Use the ASR deployment planner (https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-deployment-planner) to estimate the necessary network bandwidth requirements and the appropriate tier of storage to replicate to.\n\n          Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-rpo-exceeded , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-08-30T11:40:46.4986882Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }
    },

            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "90078",
            "errorMessage": "Replication for GRACE-Lin-3 (10.150.2.254) (/dev/sda, /dev/sdb) hasn't progressed in the last 60 minutes.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n        Replication may not be progressing due to\n        1. Network connectivity issues between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to an on-premises site)\n        2. The Azure subscription of the target storage account has been disabled.\n        3. Process server is unable to upload changes to the log/target Azure storage account, due to authentication errors.\n    ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n        1. Ensure that there is network connectivity between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master-target server if replicating to an on-premises site.)\n        2. Ensure that the \"Microsoft Azure Recovery Services Agent\", and \"InMage Scout Vx Agent - Sentinel/Outpost\" services are running on the process server machine. Try restarting these services on the process server.\n        3. Go to the Windows event viewer on the process server machine, and check for events under Applications and Services logs\\MicrosoftAzureRecoveryServices\\Replication and resolve any errors.\n        4. Log in to the replicating machine and look for the line \"Peer certificate cannot be authenticated with given CA certificates\" in the svagents.log file at  [Mobility service install location]\\ASR\\Agent\\svagents.log. If you find the line, ensure that you are running mobility service version 9.4 or higher and if not update your version.\n\n        Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-replication-not-progressing , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        If the issue persists, contact support.\n\n    ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-08-30T11:13:50.3107645Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }

            "possibleCauses": "\n        Replication may not be progressing due to\n        1.             "recommendedAction": "\n        1.             "errorCode": "90079",
            "errorMessage": "Replication for GRACE-Lin-3 (10.150.2.254) (/dev/sda, /dev/sdb) hasn't progressed in the last 30 minutes.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n        Replication not progressing.\n        Replication may not be progressing due to:\n        1. Network connectivity issues between the process server and the log/target storage account.\n        2. Capacity/IOPS limits were hit on the log/target storage account.\n        3. Authentication errors between the Process server and Azure.\n        4. The Azure subscription of the log/target storage account has been disabled.\n    ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n        1. On Windows event viewer on the source machine, check \"Applications and Services logs\\MicrosoftAzureRecoveryServices\\Replication\" for any errors and fix them.\n        2. Ensure that the source machine is running version 9.4 or higher of the mobility service.\n        3. Ensure that you are replicating to the appropriate storage account tier based on the data change rate (churn) on the source machine and that the data change rate is within Azure Site Recovery supported limits for the storage tier you are replicating to.\n        4. If you have Azure storage analytics turned on for the log/target storage account, check storage account metrics and ensure that the total requests are within the limits prescribed for this tier of storage, and that the request success percentage is good. Ensure that you have provisioned for sufficient storage IOPs capacity based on  Azure Site Recovery recommendations. Replicating too many machines to the same storage account may result in sub-optimal replication performance.\n        5. Read more here https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-replication-not-progressing\n    ",

            "errorMessage": "Replication for GRACE-V2A-WIN-1 (10.150.2.255) (Disk0, Disk1) hasn't progressed in the last 60 minutes.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n        Replication may not be progressing due to\n        1. Network connectivity issues between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to an on-premises site)\n        2. The Azure subscription of the target storage account has been disabled.\n        3. Process server is unable to upload changes to the log/target Azure storage account, due to authentication errors.\n    ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n        1. Ensure that there is network connectivity between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master-target server if replicating to an on-premises site.)\n        2. Ensure that the \"Microsoft Azure Recovery Services Agent\", and \"InMage Scout Vx Agent - Sentinel/Outpost\" services are running on the process server machine. Try restarting these services on the process server.\n        3. Go to the Windows event viewer on the process server machine, and check for events under Applications and Services logs\\MicrosoftAzureRecoveryServices\\Replication and resolve any errors.\n        4. Log in to the replicating machine and look for the line \"Peer certificate cannot be authenticated with given CA certificates\" in the svagents.log file at  [Mobility service install location]\\ASR\\Agent\\svagents.log. If you find the line, ensure that you are running mobility service version 9.4 or higher and if not update your version.\n\n        Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-replication-not-progressing , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        If the issue persists, contact support.\n\n    ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-08-30T07:38:39.1726624Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }

          "siteName": "V2A-W2K12-400"
        },
        "eventSpecificDetails": null,
        "healthErrors": [
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78026",
            "errorMessage": "RPO has exceeded the configured threshold for source disks 'Disk0'.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            The RPO for a replicating machine may be impacted if:\n            1. The machine is shutdown, the Mobility service components on the machine is not running, or the machine doesn’t have network connectivity to the process server.\n            2. The replicating machine is unable to upload changes fast enough to the process server, or the replicating machine has been flow controlled/throttled by the process server, thereby causing the machine to go into a non-data replication mode.\n            3. Recovery tag generation failures on the replicating machine.\n            4. The process server is unable to upload changes fast enough to the target/log Azure storage account (or the master target server if replicating to an on-premises site). This in turn can happen due to network connectivity issues /glitches or insufficient network throughput/bandwidth between the process server and the Azure log/target storage account.\n            5. Storage IOPs/throughput limits are being hit on the log/target storage account resulting in reduced end to end upload throughput from the process server to the log/target storage account in Azure.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          1. If there are other errors for the replicating machine, resolve them first.\n          2. See the list of recent events for the replicating machine that may be impacting the RPO of the machine by going to the events section of the recovery services vault. If there are any such events, resolve them.\n          3. Ensure that you have sufficient network bandwidth between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to on-premises site) to upload replication data, and that you are replicating to the appropriate tier of storage based on the data change rate characteristics of the replicating machine. Use the ASR deployment planner (https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-deployment-planner) to estimate the necessary network bandwidth requirements and the appropriate tier of storage to replicate to.\n\n          Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-rpo-exceeded , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-08-30T06:25:38.0878676Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }
    },

            "possibleCauses": "\n        Replication may not be progressing due to\n        1. Network connectivity issues between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to an on-premises site)\n        2. The Azure subscription of the target storage account has been disabled.\n        3. Process server is unable to upload changes to the log/target Azure storage account, due to authentication errors.\n    ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n        1. Ensure that there is network connectivity between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master-target server if replicating to an on-premises site.)\n        2. Ensure that the \"Microsoft Azure Recovery Services Agent\", and \"InMage Scout Vx Agent - Sentinel/Outpost\" services are running on the process server machine. Try restarting these services on the process server.\n        3. Go to the Windows event viewer on the process server machine, and check for events under Applications and Services logs\\MicrosoftAzureRecoveryServices\\Replication and resolve any errors.\n        4. Log in to the replicating machine and look for the line \"Peer certificate cannot be authenticated with given CA certificates\" in the svagents.log file at  [Mobility service install location]\\ASR\\Agent\\svagents.log.             "possibleCauses": "\n        Replication may not be progressing due to\n        1.             "recommendedAction": "\n        1. Log in to the replicating machine and look for the line \"Peer certificate cannot be authenticated with given CA certificates\" in the svagents.log file at  [Mobility service install location]\\ASR\\Agent\\svagents.log. If you find the line, ensure that you are running mobility service version 9.4 or higher and if not update your version.\n\n        Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-replication-not-progressing , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        If the issue persists, contact support.\n\n    ",

            "possibleCauses": "\n        Replication not progressing.\n        Replication may not be progressing due to:\n        1. Network connectivity issues between the process server and the log/target storage account.\n        2. Capacity/IOPS limits were hit on the log/target storage account.\n        3. Authentication errors between the Process server and Azure.\n        4. The Azure subscription of the log/target storage account has been disabled.\n    ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n        1. Ensure that you have provisioned for sufficient storage IOPs capacity based on  Azure Site Recovery recommendations.             "possibleCauses": "\n        Replication may not be progressing due to\n        1. Network connectivity issues between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to an on-premises site)\n        2. The Azure subscription of the target storage account has been disabled.\n        3. Process server is unable to upload changes to the log/target Azure storage account, due to authentication errors.\n    ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n        1. Ensure that there is network connectivity between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master-target server if replicating to an on-premises site.)\n        2. Ensure that the \"Microsoft Azure Recovery Services Agent\", and \"InMage Scout Vx Agent - Sentinel/Outpost\" services are running on the process server machine. Try restarting these services on the process server.\n        3. Go to the Windows event viewer on the process server machine, and check for events under Applications and Services logs\\MicrosoftAzureRecoveryServices\\Replication and resolve any errors.\n        4. Log in to the replicating machine and look for the line \"Peer certificate cannot be authenticated with given CA certificates\" in the svagents.log file at  [Mobility service install location]\\ASR\\Agent\\svagents.log. If you find the line, ensure that you are running mobility service version 9.4 or higher and if not update your version.\n\n        Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-replication-not-progressing , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        If the issue persists, contact support.\n\n    ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-08-29T17:03:41.6642203Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          },
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "90079",
            "errorMessage": "Replication for ScaleWinSrc02 (10.150.209.239) (Disk0) hasn't progressed in the last 30 minutes.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n        Replication not progressing.\n        Replication may not be progressing due to:\n        1. Network connectivity issues between the process server and the log/target storage account.\n        2. Capacity/IOPS limits were hit on the log/target storage account.\n        3. Authentication errors between the Process server and Azure.\n        4. The Azure subscription of the log/target storage account has been disabled.\n    ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n        1. On Windows event viewer on the source machine, check \"Applications and Services logs\\MicrosoftAzureRecoveryServices\\Replication\" for any errors and fix them.\n        2. Ensure that the source machine is running version 9.4 or higher of the mobility service.\n        3. Ensure that you are replicating to the appropriate storage account tier based on the data change rate (churn) on the source machine and that the data change rate is within Azure Site Recovery supported limits for the storage tier you are replicating to.\n        4. If you have Azure storage analytics turned on for the log/target storage account, check storage account metrics and ensure that the total requests are within the limits prescribed for this tier of storage, and that the request success percentage is good. Ensure that you have provisioned for sufficient storage IOPs capacity based on  Azure Site Recovery recommendations. Replicating too many machines to the same storage account may result in sub-optimal replication performance.\n        5. Read more here https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-replication-not-progressing\n    ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-08-29T17:03:41.6642203Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }

            "errorMessage": "Replication for ScaleWinSrc10 (10.150.2.165) (Disk0) hasn't progressed in the last 60 minutes.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n        Replication may not be progressing due to\n        1. Network connectivity issues between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to an on-premises site)\n        2. The Azure subscription of the target storage account has been disabled.\n        3. Process server is unable to upload changes to the log/target Azure storage account, due to authentication errors.\n    ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n        1. Ensure that there is network connectivity between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master-target server if replicating to an on-premises site.)\n        2. Ensure that the \"Microsoft Azure Recovery Services Agent\", and \"InMage Scout Vx Agent - Sentinel/Outpost\" services are running on the process server machine. Try restarting these services on the process server.\n        3. Go to the Windows event viewer on the process server machine, and check for events under Applications and Services logs\\MicrosoftAzureRecoveryServices\\Replication and resolve any errors.\n        4. Log in to the replicating machine and look for the line \"Peer certificate cannot be authenticated with given CA certificates\" in the svagents.log file at  [Mobility service install location]\\ASR\\Agent\\svagents.log. If you find the line, ensure that you are running mobility service version 9.4 or higher and if not update your version.\n\n        Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-replication-not-progressing , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        If the issue persists, contact support.\n\n    ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-08-29T13:49:40.255199Z",

            "possibleCauses": "\n        Replication may not be progressing due to\n        1. The Azure subscription of the target storage account has been disabled.\n        3. Process server is unable to upload changes to the log/target Azure storage account, due to authentication errors.\n    ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n        1. Go to the Windows event viewer on the process server machine, and check for events under Applications and Services logs\\MicrosoftAzureRecoveryServices\\Replication and resolve any errors.\n        4. Log in to the replicating machine and look for the line \"Peer certificate cannot be authenticated with given CA certificates\" in the svagents.log file at  [Mobility service install location]\\ASR\\Agent\\svagents.log. If you find the line, ensure that you are running mobility service version 9.4 or higher and if not update your version.\n\n        Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-replication-not-progressing , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        If the issue persists, contact support.\n\n    ",

            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "90079",
            "errorMessage": "Replication for ScaleWinSrc24 (10.150.3.221) (Disk0, Disk1) hasn't progressed in the last 30 minutes.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n        Replication not progressing.\n        Replication may not be progressing due to:\n        1. Network connectivity issues between the process server and the log/target storage account.\n        2. Capacity/IOPS limits were hit on the log/target storage account.\n        3. Authentication errors between the Process server and Azure.\n        4. The Azure subscription of the log/target storage account has been disabled.\n    ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n        1. On Windows event viewer on the source machine, check \"Applications and Services logs\\MicrosoftAzureRecoveryServices\\Replication\" for any errors and fix them.\n        2. Ensure that the source machine is running version 9.4 or higher of the mobility service.\n        3. Ensure that you are replicating to the appropriate storage account tier based on the data change rate (churn) on the source machine and that the data change rate is within Azure Site Recovery supported limits for the storage tier you are replicating to.\n        4. If you have Azure storage analytics turned on for the log/target storage account, check storage account metrics and ensure that the total requests are within the limits prescribed for this tier of storage, and that the request success percentage is good. Ensure that you have provisioned for sufficient storage IOPs capacity based on  Azure Site Recovery recommendations. Replicating too many machines to the same storage account may result in sub-optimal replication performance.\n        5. Read more here https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-replication-not-progressing\n    ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-08-29T12:41:44.0094446Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]

            "errorMessage": "Replication for ScaleWinSrc17 (10.150.3.214) (Disk0, Disk1) hasn't progressed in the last 60 minutes.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n        Replication may not be progressing due to\n        1. Network connectivity issues between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to an on-premises site)\n        2. The Azure subscription of the target storage account has been disabled.\n        3. Process server is unable to upload changes to the log/target Azure storage account, due to authentication errors.\n    ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n        1. Ensure that there is network connectivity between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master-target server if replicating to an on-premises site.)\n        2. Ensure that the \"Microsoft Azure Recovery Services Agent\", and \"InMage Scout Vx Agent - Sentinel/Outpost\" services are running on the process server machine. Try restarting these services on the process server.\n        3. Go to the Windows event viewer on the process server machine, and check for events under Applications and Services logs\\MicrosoftAzureRecoveryServices\\Replication and resolve any errors.\n        4. Log in to the replicating machine and look for the line \"Peer certificate cannot be authenticated with given CA certificates\" in the svagents.log file at  [Mobility service install location]\\ASR\\Agent\\svagents.log. If you find the line, ensure that you are running mobility service version 9.4 or higher and if not update your version.\n\n        Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-replication-not-progressing , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        If the issue persists, contact support.\n\n    ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-08-29T12:41:39.9156655Z",

If you have Azure storage analytics turned on for the log/target storage account, check storage account metrics and ensure that the total requests are within the limits prescribed for this tier of storage, and that the request success percentage is good. Ensure that you have provisioned for sufficient storage IOPs capacity based on  Azure Site Recovery recommendations. Ensure that the \"Microsoft Azure Recovery Services Agent\", and \"InMage Scout Vx Agent - Sentinel/Outpost\" services are running on the process server machine. Try restarting these services on the process server.\n        3. Go to the Windows event viewer on the process server machine, and check for events under Applications and Services logs\\MicrosoftAzureRecoveryServices\\Replication and resolve any errors.\n        4. Log in to the replicating machine and look for the line \"Peer certificate cannot be authenticated with given CA certificates\" in the svagents.log file at  [Mobility service install location]\\ASR\\Agent\\svagents.log. If you find the line, ensure that you are running mobility service version 9.4 or higher and if not update your version.\n\n        Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-replication-not-progressing , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        If the issue persists, contact support.\n\n    ",

            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null

            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "90079",
            "errorMessage": "Replication for ScaleWinSrc10 (10.150.2.165) (Disk0) hasn't progressed in the last 30 minutes.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n        Replication not progressing.\n        Replication may not be progressing due to:\n        1. Network connectivity issues between the process server and the log/target storage account.\n        2. Capacity/IOPS limits were hit on the log/target storage account.\n        3. Authentication errors between the Process server and Azure.\n        4. The Azure subscription of the log/target storage account has been disabled.\n    ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n        1. On Windows event viewer on the source machine, check \"Applications and Services logs\\MicrosoftAzureRecoveryServices\\Replication\" for any errors and fix them.\n        2. Ensure that the source machine is running version 9.4 or higher of the mobility service.\n        3. Ensure that you are replicating to the appropriate storage account tier based on the data change rate (churn) on the source machine and that the data change rate is within Azure Site Recovery supported limits for the storage tier you are replicating to.\n        4. If you have Azure storage analytics turned on for the log/target storage account, check storage account metrics and ensure that the total requests are within the limits prescribed for this tier of storage, and that the request success percentage is good. Ensure that you have provisioned for sufficient storage IOPs capacity based on  Azure Site Recovery recommendations. Replicating too many machines to the same storage account may result in sub-optimal replication performance.\n        5. Read more here https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-replication-not-progressing\n    ",

Network connectivity issues between the process server and the log/target storage account.\n        2. Capacity/IOPS limits were hit on the log/target storage account.\n        3. Authentication errors between the Process server and Azure.\n        4. The Azure subscription of the log/target storage account has been disabled.\n    ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n        1. On Windows event viewer on the source machine, check \"Applications and Services logs\\MicrosoftAzureRecoveryServices\\Replication\" for any errors and fix them.\n        2. Ensure that the source machine is running version 9.4 or higher of the mobility service.\n        3. Ensure that you are replicating to the appropriate storage account tier based on the data change rate (churn) on the source machine and that the data change rate is within Azure Site Recovery supported limits for the storage tier you are replicating to.\n        4. If you have Azure storage analytics turned on for the log/target storage account, check storage account metrics and ensure that the total requests are within the limits prescribed for this tier of storage, and that the request success percentage is good. Ensure that you have provisioned for sufficient storage IOPs capacity based on  Azure Site Recovery recommendations. Replicating too many machines to the same storage account may result in sub-optimal replication performance.\n        5. Read more here https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-replication-not-progressing\n    ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-08-29T12:24:56.0842395Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]

            "possibleCauses": "\n        Replication may not be progressing due to\n        1. Network connectivity issues between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to an on-premises site)\n        2. The Azure subscription of the target storage account has been disabled.\n        3. Process server is unable to upload changes to the log/target Azure storage account, due to authentication errors.\n    ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n        1. Ensure that there is network connectivity between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master-target server if replicating to an on-premises site.)\n        2. Ensure that the \"Microsoft Azure Recovery Services Agent\", and \"InMage Scout Vx Agent - Sentinel/Outpost\" services are running on the process server machine. Try restarting these services on the process server.\n        3. Go to the Windows event viewer on the process server machine, and check for events under Applications and Services logs\\MicrosoftAzureRecoveryServices\\Replication and resolve any errors.\n        4. Log in to the replicating machine and look for the line \"Peer certificate cannot be authenticated with given CA certificates\" in the svagents.log file at  [Mobility service install location]\\ASR\\Agent\\svagents.log. If you find the line, ensure that you are running mobility service version 9.4 or higher and if not update your version.\n\n        Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-replication-not-progressing , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        If the issue persists, contact support.\n\n    ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-08-29T12:24:56.068589Z",

            "errorMessage": "Replication health of ScaleWinSrc01 is critical as the Azure Site Recovery mobility service software has been uninstalled from the machine.",
            "possibleCauses": "Mobility service software on the source machine has been uninstalled.",
            "recommendedAction": "\n            The source machine isn’t being replicated as the mobility service software has been uninstalled, but can be failed over to the latest available recovery point.           {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78174",
            "errorMessage": "No heartbeat received from the mobility service on the source machine 'prgoyal-ubuntu1404' in the last 15 minutes.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            1. The mobility service is not running on the source machine\n            2. There is no network connectivity from the source machine to the configuration server.\n            3. The source machine is not up\n            4. The source machine is running a version of the mobility service older than 9.4 and is unable to authenticate with the configuration server\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          Ensure that\n          1) The source machine is up and that the mobility service(\"InMage Scout VX Agent - Sentinel/Outpost\", and  \"InMage Scout Application Service\") is running on the host\n          2) The source machines has network connectivity to the configuration server on the configuration server tcp port 443.\n          3) If the mobility service version on the machine is 9.3 or lower, upgrade to the latest version of the mobility service\n          Read more at https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-no-heartbeat.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-08-29T10:05:43.5459414Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          }
        ]
      }

        "healthErrors": [
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78026",
            "errorMessage": "RPO has exceeded the configured threshold for source disks 'Disk0, Disk2'.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            The RPO for a replicating machine may be impacted if:\n            1. The machine is shutdown, the Mobility service components on the machine is not running, or the machine doesn’t have network connectivity to the process server.\n            2. The replicating machine is unable to upload changes fast enough to the process server, or the replicating machine has been flow controlled/throttled by the process server, thereby causing the machine to go into a non-data replication mode.\n            3. Recovery tag generation failures on the replicating machine.\n            4. The process server is unable to upload changes fast enough to the target/log Azure storage account (or the master target server if replicating to an on-premises site). This in turn can happen due to network connectivity issues /glitches or insufficient network throughput/bandwidth between the process server and the Azure log/target storage account.\n            5. Storage IOPs/throughput limits are being hit on the log/target storage account resulting in reduced end to end upload throughput from the process server to the log/target storage account in Azure.\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          1. If there are other errors for the replicating machine, resolve them first.\n          2. See the list of recent events for the replicating machine that may be impacting the RPO of the machine by going to the events section of the recovery services vault. If there are any such events, resolve them.\n          3. Ensure that you have sufficient network bandwidth between the process server and the log/target Azure storage account (or master target server if replicating to on-premises site) to upload replication data, and that you are replicating to the appropriate tier of storage based on the data change rate characteristics of the replicating machine. Use the ASR deployment planner (https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-deployment-planner) to estimate the necessary network bandwidth requirements and the appropriate tier of storage to replicate to.\n\n          Refer to the article https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-rpo-exceeded , to learn how to troubleshoot replication issues.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-08-29T10:05:43.0627209Z",
            "recoveryProviderErrorMessage": null,
            "entityId": null
          },
          {
            "errorSource": null,
            "errorType": null,
            "errorLevel": null,
            "errorCode": "78174",
            "errorMessage": "No heartbeat received from the mobility service on the source machine 'PRGOYAL-TEST4' in the last 15 minutes.",
            "possibleCauses": "\n            1. The mobility service is not running on the source machine\n            2. There is no network connectivity from the source machine to the configuration server.\n            3. The source machine is not up\n            4. The source machine is running a version of the mobility service older than 9.4 and is unable to authenticate with the configuration server\n        ",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          Ensure that\n          1) The source machine is up and that the mobility service(\"InMage Scout VX Agent - Sentinel/Outpost\", and  \"InMage Scout Application Service\") is running on the host\n          2) The source machines has network connectivity to the configuration server on the configuration server tcp port 443.\n          3) If the mobility service version on the machine is 9.3 or lower, upgrade to the latest version of the mobility service\n          Read more at https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-no-heartbeat.\n        ",
            "creationTimeUtc": "2017-08-29T10:05:43.0627209Z",

            "possibleCauses": "The mobility service is not running on the host. There is no network connectivity from the host to the configuration server.",
            "recommendedAction": "\n          Ensure that the mobility service(InMage Scout VX Agent - Sentinel/Outpost, InMage Scout Application Service) is running on the host, host is connected to a network and the configuration server is reachable from the host.\n          Read more at https://aka.ms/asr-v2a-no-heartbeat.\n        ",
